Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the code sample from my mentor half-finished. He’d been clear: “Have this ready before our next meeting in three days.” I wanted to impress him, to show I was committed and capable. But as I glanced at my phone, a reminder popped up—church service tomorrow, followed by the community outreach I’d promised to help with. As a Christian, I knew how important it was to be present, to worship and serve alongside my church family. They counted on me, and I believed in the value of showing up, of living my faith in action.

But the code wasn’t going to write itself. If I spent the whole day at church, I’d lose precious hours. My mentor expected dedication, and I didn’t want to let him down. Yet, skipping church felt like turning my back on my faith and my community. The pressure built inside me, a knot of anxiety tightening in my chest. I wanted to be a good mentee and a faithful Christian, but right now, it felt impossible to be both.
